challengeName: Retailer Loyalty App - Convert Prototype into Ionic App
detailedRequirements:
Challenge Introduction:
Welcome to the Retailer Loyalty Mobile App Design Concepts Challenge. Our client is a leading agriculture company that supplies it’s products to Retailers. Visibility into retailer inventory and their sales of our clients products is very limited and the process is manual.  Retailers receive our client's products but do not report back on actual sales nor inventory.  There is also no formal loyalty process that includes retailers.

 

The Agriculture company supplies products like Fertilizer, Herbicide, Pesticide, Fungicide, Plant Tonic.

 

Our client would like a mobile application to automate this Retailer Loyalty process. The app will add value in facilitating the Retailer on-boarding process, update product inventory at point of sale and encourage retailers to engage with our client in the form of a Retailer Loyalty feature.

 

The app will enable our clients Sales agents to engage with their retailers, view specific data related to each retailer, and gain valuable insight into actual products sold.  Our clients Sales agents can further engage with the retailer via the Retailer Loyalty feature.

 

At the end of this challenge, we are looking for the Topcoder Community to take the existing clickable prototype built in HTML, CSS and Javascript and convert it to an Ionic Cordova app for Android.

Challenge Description:
A leading Agriculture company would like an app to increase visibility of stock within their retailers. The current model is not scalable and requires sales reps to conduct regular visits to their retailers. Furthermore, there is a significant dependency on retailers to to keep track of products which both enter and leave their physical retail site, which leads to data integrity issues. As a result visibility of sales is poor and it is challenging to reward loyal retailers.

 

General Notes

- We’ve included the Gitlab repository for NodeJS backend (ask for access in the forums). Please follow the instructions for setting up the backend on your local dev machine. You’ll be required to integrate the Ionic app with the backend for this challenge.

- Use Ionic components/directives (ion-list, ion-item, etc.) as much as possible, providing they exactly match the behaviour and styling of the HTML prototype (see below). You can use the Sass variables for the ionic directives for customising the style to fit the app.

- If the Ionic component/directive does not exactly match the HTML prototype, then you should create an Ionic component/directive

- Replace the use of JQuery in prototype with Angular/Ionic.

- Consider how you might employ view caching to improve the user experience

- You need to handle offline support with respect to syncing of scanned products (sold and added to stock)

- You need to follow the Ionic best practice in this contest.

- The converted prototype should exactly match the provided HTML, CSS, Javascript prototype.

- Your design needs to be responsive, so in different screen sizes the application can adjust the layout accordingly.

- You are building an Ionic Cordova app in this contest, with Android as the target platform

- All screens need to use fluid layout when transform into Landscape or Portrait view.

 

Clickable (HTML) Prototype

- We have built a clickable prototype in HTML, CSS and Javascript, please request access to the Gitlab repository in the forums

- You can also see the InVision screens here https://topcoder.invisionapp.com/share/H99BEE3X3#/screens/204857873

- Note that mobile gestures (i.e. swipe left/right) will not work on the desktop browser, you need to open the link in your mobile to experience it.

 

Integration with Auth0

You are expected to complete the integration with Auth0. There are endpoints in the NodeJS backend for registration, login etc. We are aware that alterations might need to be made to the registration and login screens to make this work. Please post in the forums if need to make changes.

 

Integration with the NodeJS backend

You are expected to complete the integration with the NodeJS backend. Below you’ll find a table that shows which endpoints to use for a given screen.

 

End-point

Barcode scanner

For the Barcode scanner we suggest you use the ngCordova Barcode Scanner plugin http://ngcordova.com/docs/plugins/barcodeScanner/

 

You’re also welcome to try using this library for the Barcode Scanner but it might prove to be more challenging to integrate with Cordova https://serratus.github.io/quaggaJS/

 

Push Notifications

- When a Retailer sends an Inquiry to an Agent the agent receives a push notification. When an Agent replies to an Inquiry the Retailer receives push notification and vice versa.

 

Application Users:

The app may be run by a Retailer, or an Agent (one of our staff). This is the description of each of the roles:

Retailer: A Retailer buys products from us (be it directly or also from the market) and sells them further to his customers. He scans the products when they arrive, to build his inventory, and check for any counterfeit products (in case he gets them from the market), and scans them again when he sells them, in order to collect loyalty points. A Retailer is connected only to one Agent.

Agent: An Agent is a salesperson working for our company. He is allocated to a certain Country and has a pool of Retailers that are associated with him and for which he is the person of contact. The Agent can only see the data associated to his own Retailers. He cannot see the Retailers of other Agents.

 

Screens:

The functionality and features for each screen are described below. There are specific links to the screens in InVision for reference. However, to understand how the prototype works you should build the HTML, CSS, Javascript prototype - the InVision links are just for quick reference.

 

00 Splash Page:

- The percentage loading should match the app loading. At the moment there is a fake timer which was implemented in the clickable prototype for demo purposes; the fake timer should be removed.

 

01 Getting Started:

- The ‘Next’ button moves through the screens as well as the swipe left and right gestures. Ensure this is maintained.

 

A. Retailer:

02 Registration:

- First time Retailers will need to register with the application.

- We have removed this screen because only Retailers need to register with the app (agents will already have a username and password).

- They will enter the basic details, username, password, name of person, retailer name, address (location), Retailer ID, etc

- They should also have the ability to register through social login (some details will be captured if they use this and still show the registration step with few fields already populated as data is captured from the social network)

- On successful registration, we show a success message informing their account has been created.

- Provide input field validation.

 

03 Login:

- Should be able to login with their username and password

- Retailer will be able to Social login i.e. could use his social profiles to login into this app.

- Provide ability to retrieve password (‘Auth0 Database’ only)

- If Remember is checked then each time they start the app they should not have to login i.e. taken from Splash screen to Dashboard.

 

04 Dashboard:

- The tile functionality where you can add/remove/reposition tiles must be maintained (play around with the HTML prototype to see how this works). We’d like to implement this feature using Angular and not JQuery. Cache the configuration for the tiles so that next time the user uses the app the tiles are how they left them.

- ‘My Agent’ tile - the email, phone and message buttons should work. Tapping the email icon should launch the native email client. Tapping phone icon should launch the native dialer with the agent number pre-populated. Tapping the message icon button should launch a new Inquiry

- ‘Statistics’ tile - the chart should start from the current date. The current date should be displayed at the bottom of the chart.

- ‘Recent Inventory’ tile - sold / stock (depending on filter selected) should show the ten most recent items in descending data order. ‘All Inventory’ links to ‘My Inventory’.

- Note: there are two dashboard links in the hamburger menu. There should be only one. The ‘My Retailers’ link should not show in the hamburger menu when the user is a Retailer.

 

05 My Inventory:

- ‘All’ - shows all items (stock and sold). Default sort order is by most recent items in descending timestamp order. Default filter is that there is no filtering. By dragging down, the search box is displayed (see the HTML prototype).

- ‘Stock’ and ‘Sold’ tabs apply the stock/sold ‘item type’ filter as appropriate. The ‘item type’ filter is disabled when on ‘Stock’ or ‘Sold’ tabs.

- Apply sorting and filtering as appropriate.

- Tapping the product takes the user to the Product Detail screen.

- The the three vertical dots next to each product display ‘more detail’ and ‘contact agent’ options. ‘More details’ takes the user to the the Product Detail screen. ‘Contact agent’ takes the user to the Inquiry screen with the product details pre-populated.

- The ‘+’ FAB (Floating Action Button) should show two options. ‘Scan barcode’ should be removed. The icons for ‘Sell Product’ and ‘Add Inventory’ should be changed. ‘Sell Product’ should use the ‘Scan barcode’ icon. ‘Add Inventory’ should use the ‘Sell Product’ icon. Tapping ‘Sell Product’ should take the user to ‘05 Barcode Scanning’ with ‘Sold’ tab pre-selected. Tapping ‘Add Inventory’ should take the user to ‘05 Barcode Scanning’ with ‘Incoming’ pre-selected.

- The bottom-left hand corner shows the total number of loyalty points.

 

05 Barcode Scanning:

- Implement Barcode scanning in Ionic. Refer to ‘Barcode scanner’ section of the challenge.

- Only show ‘Scan Another’ and ‘Contact Agent’ buttons if a scan fails. Successful scanning should show the ‘Scanning Success!’ message and allow continual scanning of products in both modes (Incoming/Sold).

- ‘Sold’ mode is for selling products. ‘Incoming’ mode is for adding products to stock. Refer to the API section of the challenge for more information.

- Scan Activity - you’ll need to handle cases where the user does not have an Internet connection but needs to scan products. The clock icon next to a product indicates that the product has not been synced to the backend, probably because the user didn’t have an Internet connection at the time they scanned the product. These products should be stored on the device until the user has an Internet connection again. The user can sync the products by pulling down on the ‘sold’ or ‘incoming’ lists in the Scan Activity’ view.

 

06 Notifications:

- In this view the user can see notifications from all Inquiries (open, resolved (closed)) in the ‘All’ tab. Change the name of the ‘Inquiries’ tab to ‘Open’, and only show the open inquiries. The ‘tick’ icon indicates that an inquiry has a status of ‘closed’ (resolved).

 

07 Inquiry:

-  The inquiry screen allows the user to create a new Inquiry with their agent

 

B. Agent:

07 Agent Dashboard:

- The tile functionality (add/remove/reposition) should be maintained. You can re-use the implementation for the Retailer.

- ‘My Profile’ - the graph icon takes the user to the Leaderboard. The people icon takes the user to ‘My Retailers’ (as is already implemented)

- Rename ‘Salling Statistics’ to ‘Sales’. The chart should start from the current date. The current date should be displayed at the bottom of the chart

- Hamburger menu should show ‘Dashboard’, ‘Notifications’ and ‘My Retailers’ only

- ‘Recent Inquiries’, ‘My Retailers’ and ‘Leaderboard’ should all be hooked up to the backend appropriately.

 

08 My Retailers:

- Default sort order is by total number of loyalty points in descending order.

- ‘Retailer Detail’ - the Phone and Email links on the ‘About’ tab should launch the native dialer and mail applications respectively. ‘Inquiry’ tab should show the inquiries with the agent for that retailer. Most recent open inquiries should be at the top. ‘Points’ tab should be renamed ‘Sales’ - the list of products shown under the graph defaults to the products sold by the Retailer on the current day. Tapping a different day will show the products sold for that day.

 

09 Notifications:

- In this view the user can see notifications from all Inquiries (open, resolved (closed)) in the ‘All’ tab. Change the name of the ‘Inquiries’ tab to ‘Open’, and only show the open inquiries. The ‘tick’ icon indicates that an inquiry has a status of ‘closed’ (resolved).

 

Specific HTML/CSS/JavaScript Requirements

 

- You must use HTML5 and CSS3

-  Use Sass for Ionic as described here. The existing prototype uses Sass but you should integrate the Sass in an Ionic way using imports and styling Ionic directives using Sass variables where appropriate

- Validate your code - reviewers may accept minor validation errors, but please comment your reason for any validation errors. Use the validators listed in the scorecard.

- Use CSS to space out objects, not clear/transparent images (GIFs or PNGs) and use proper structural CSS to lay out your page. Only use table tags for tables of data/information and not for page layout.

- No inline CSS styles - all styles must be placed in an external stylesheet.

- Use semantically correct tags - use H tags for headers, etc. Use strong and em tags instead of bold and italic tags.

- Element and Attribute names should be in lowercase and use a "-" or camel naming to separate multiple-word classes (i.e.. "main-content", or "mainContent).

- Label all CSS, JavaScript, or HTML hacks with explanations so others will understand.

 

Specific Ionic Requirements

- Use Ionic 2

- Use a “Folders-by-Component” structure that is now the default in Angular2/Ionic2 applications

- Use the Ionic CLI to install Platforms and Plugins

- Enable Native Scrolling
finalSubmissionGuidelines:
- Zipped source code
- Deployment Guide with instructions on how to bulid and run your submission
- Demo video showing the app running on device/ emulator for phone & tablet
- The winning member will be expected to submit a merge request to the mobile app Gitlab repo
